    ◦ Gastrointestinal and Systemic Effects: Ingestion leads to vomiting, diarrhea, weakness, and labored breathing1.

symptoms.name: Liver Failure
symptoms.onset: Delayed (typically occurs after the initial gastrointestinal signs).
symptoms.notes: While the sources note that liver failure from Lantana is more commonly documented in livestock (cattle/sheep), it remains a potential risk for companion animals like cats and dogs.common plants that are toxic to cats | Petbarn Articles (Conversation History)

treatments.name: Induction of Emesis (Vomiting) and Gastric Lavage
treatments.description: If the ingestion is recent (typically within 1–2 hours) and the cat is neurologically stable, the veterinarian will administer medication (such as xylazine) to induce vomiting and remove the plant material from the stomach. In life-threatening cases or if vomiting cannot be induced safely, the stomach may be pumped (gastric lavage) to wash out contents.
treatments.notes: Decontamination is most effective when performed early. Owners should not attempt to induce vomiting at home with hydrogen peroxide or salt, as this can cause severe injury; this procedure requires veterinary supervision.Toxin Adsorption

treatments.name: Administration of Activated Charcoal
treatments.description: Following emesis, the veterinarian administers activated charcoal, often with a cathartic. This substance binds to the remaining toxins in the gastrointestinal tract, preventing them from being absorbed into the bloodstream.
treatments.notes: Because some plant toxins undergo "enterohepatic recirculation" (recycling through the liver), multiple doses of activated charcoal every 6–8 hours may be necessary to minimize ongoing liver damage.Hepatic and Systemic Support

treatments.name: Intravenous (IV) Fluid Therapy
treatments.description: IV fluids are administered to maintain hydration, correct electrolyte imbalances caused by vomiting and diarrhea, and support organ function by flushing toxins from the body.
treatments.notes: Since Lantana toxicity can lead to liver failure, maintaining adequate perfusion to the liver and kidneys is critical. Fluid therapy helps manage the hypotension (low blood pressure) and dehydration often associated with severe plant poisoning.Symptomatic Care and Monitoring

treatments.name: Hepatoprotectants and Anti-emetics
treatments.description: Veterinarians may administer liver-protecting medications (such as SAMe or N-acetylcysteine) to support liver repair. Medications to stop vomiting (anti-emetics) and protect the stomach lining (gastroprotectants) are used to treat severe gastrointestinal upset.
treatments.notes: Lantana ingestion can cause labored breathing and weakness; therefore, continuous monitoring of vital signs and liver enzymes is essential to assess the progression of toxicity.
